Does Kerbol rotate? You would need to know how fast it spins to determine the altitude.

If you meant Kerbin, then it's 2870km at 1008.9m/s

I'm talking about Kerbol, the sun.
Stars don't have solid surfaces, and different lattitudes rotate at different rates. There's no single rotational period for anyone to match. And since there are no (permanent) surface features to synchronize with either, I'm curious as to why you want to do this? Edited September 3, 2012 by Vanamonde
Also, isn't Kerbol only a point-object right now? There's no surface at all to rotate.

Ah, I guess not rotating does make this a problem.

Stars don't have solid surfaces, and different lattitudes rotate at different rates. There's no single rotational period for anyone to match. And since there are no (permanent) surface features to synchronize with either, I'm curious as to why you want to do this?

You can easily demonstrate this by switching between Orbital and Surface velocity while in interplanetary space; They will always have identical values.
